verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 44:5
verses.text: "If," says Aquila, "those things which are done disorderly do not allow you say that they are done by the providence of God, why do not those things which are done orderly compel you to say that they are done by God, and that irrational nature cannot produce a rational work? For it is certain, nor do we at all deny, that in this world some things are done orderly, and some disorderly.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 44:6
verses.text: Those things, therefore, that are done rationally, believe that they are done by providence; but those that are done irrationally and inordinately, that they befall naturally, and happen accidentally.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 44:7
verses.text: But I wonder that men do not perceive, that where there is sense things may be done ordinately and inordinately, but where there is no sense neither the one nor the other can be done; for reason makes order, and the course of order necessarily produces something inordinate, if anything contrary happen to disturb order".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 44:8
verses.text: Then the old man: "This very thing I wish you to show me".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 45:1
verses.text: Chapter XLV.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 45:2
verses.text: —Motions of the Sun and Moon.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 45:3
verses.text: Says Aquila: "I shall do so without delay.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 45:4
verses.text: Two visible signs are shown in heaven—one of the sun, the other of the moon; and these are followed by five other stars, each describing its own separate orbit.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 45:5
verses.text: These, therefore, God has placed in the heaven, by which the temperature of the air may be regulated according to the seasons, and the order of vicissitudes and alternations may be kept.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 45:6
verses.text: But by means of the very same signs, if at any time plague and corruption is sent upon the earth for the sins of men, the air is disturbed, pestilence is brought upon animals, blight upon crops, and a destructive year in every way upon men; and thus it is that by one and the same means order is both kept and destroyed.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 45:7
verses.text: For it is manifest even to the unbelieving and unskilful, that the course of the sun, which is useful and necessary to the world, and which is assigned by providence, is always kept orderly; but the courses of the moon, in comparison of the course of the sun, seem to the unskilful to be inordinate and unsettled in her waxings and wanings.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 45:8
verses.text: For the sun moves in fixed and orderly periods: for from him are hours, from him the day when he rises, from him also the night when he sets; from him months and years are reckoned, from him the variations of seasons are produced; while, rising to the higher regions, he tempers the spring; but when he reaches the top of the heaven, he kindles the summer's heats: again, sinking, he produces the temper of autumn; and when he returns to his lowest circle, he bequeaths to us the rigour of winter's cold from the icy binding of heaven.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 46:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVI.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 46:2
verses.text: —Sun and Moon Ministers Both of Good and Evil.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 46:3
verses.text: "But we shall discourse at greater length on these subjects at another time.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 46:4
verses.text: Now, meantime, we remark that though he is that good servant for regulating the changes of the seasons, yet, when chastisement is inflicted upon men according to the will of God, he glows more fiercely, and burns up the world with more vehement fires.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 46:5
verses.text: In like manner also the course of the moon, and that changing which seems to the unskilful to be disorderly, is adapted to the growth of crops, and cattle, and all living creatures; for by her waxings and wanings, by a certain wonderful contrivance of providence, everything that is born is nourished and grows; concerning which we could speak more at length and unfold the matter in detail, but that the method of the question proposed recalls us.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 46:6
verses.text: Yet, by the very same appliances by which they are produced, all things are nourished and increased; but when, from any just cause, the regulation of the appointed order is changed, corruption and distemper arise, so that chastisement may come upon men by the will of God, as we have said above.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 47:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVII.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 47:2
verses.text: —Chastisements on the Righteous and the Wicked.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 47:3
verses.text: "But perhaps you will say, What of the fact that, in that common chastisement, like things befall the pious and the impious? It is true, and we confess it; but the chastisement turns to the advantage of the pious, that, being afflicted in the present life, they may come more purified to the future, in which perpetual rest is prepared for them, and that at the same time even the impious may somewhat profit from their chastisement, or else that the just sentence of the future judgment may be passed upon them; since in the same chastisements the righteous give thanks to God, while the unrighteous blaspheme.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 47:4
verses.text: Therefore, since the opinion of things is divided into two parts, that some things are done by order and others against order, it ought, from those things which are done according to order, to be believed that there is a providence; but with respect to those things which are done against order, we should inquire their causes from those who have learned them by prophetic teaching: for those who have become acquainted with prophetic discourse know when, and for what reason, blight, hail, and pestilence, and such like, have occurred in every generation, and for what sins these have been sent as a punishment; whence causes of sadness, lamentations, and griefs have befallen the human race; whence also trembling sickness has ensued, and that this has been from the beginning the punishment of parricide.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 48:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVIII.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 48:2
verses.text: —Chastisements for Sins.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 48:3
verses.text: "For in the beginning of the world there were none of these evils, but they took their rise from the impiety of men; and thence, with the constant increase of iniquities, the number of evils has also increased.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 48:4
verses.text: But for this reason divine providence has decreed a judgment with respect to all men, because the present life was not such that every one could be dealt with according to his deservings.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 48:5
verses.text: Those things, therefore, which were well and orderly appointed from the beginning, when no causes of evil existed, are not to be judged of from the evils which have befallen the world by reason of the sins of men.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 48:6
verses.text: In short, as an indication of the things which were from the beginning, some nations are found which are strangers to these evils.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 48:7
verses.text: For the Seres, because they live chastely, are kept free from them all; for with them it is unlawful to come at a woman after she has conceived, or while she is being purified.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 48:8
verses.text: No one there eats unclean flesh, no one knows aught of sacrifices; all are judges to themselves according to justice.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 48:9
verses.text: For this reason they are not chastened with those plagues which we have spoken of; they live to extreme old age, and die without sickness.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 48:10
verses.text: But we, miserable as we are, dwelling as it were with deadly serpents—I mean with wicked men—necessarily suffer with them the plagues of afflictions in this world, but we cherish hope from the comfort of good things to come".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 49:1
verses.text: Chapter XLIX.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 49:2
verses.text: —God's Precepts Despised.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 49:3
verses.text: "If," said the old man, "even the righteous are tormented on account of the iniquities of others, God ought, as foreseeing this, to have commanded men not to do those things from which it should be necessary that the righteous be afflicted with the unrighteous; or if they did them, He ought to have applied some correction or purification to the world".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 49:4
verses.text: "God," said Aquila, "did so command, and gave precepts by the prophets how men ought to live; but even these precepts they despised: yea, if any desired to observe them, them they afflicted with various injuries, until they drove them from their purposed observance, and turned them to the rabble of infidelity, and made them like unto themselves.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 50:1
verses.text: Chapter L.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 50:2
verses.text: —The Flood.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 50:3
verses.text: "Wherefore, in short, at the first, when all the earth had been stained with sins, God brought a flood upon the world, which you say happened under Deucalion; and at that time He saved a certain righteous man, with his sons, in an ark, and with him the race of all plants and animals.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 50:4
verses.text: And yet even those who sprang from them, after a time, again did deeds like to those of their predecessors; for those things that had befallen them were forgotten, so that their descendants did not even believe that the flood had taken place.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 50:5
verses.text: Wherefore God also decreed that there should not be another flood in the present world, else there should have been one in every generation, according to the account of their sins by reason of their unbelief; but He rather granted that certain angels who delight in evil should bear sway over the several nations—and to them was given power over individual men, yet only on this condition, if any one first had made himself subject to them by sinning—until He should come who delights in good, and by Him the number of the righteous should be completed, and by the increase of the number of pious men all over the world impiety should be in some measure repressed, and it should be known to all that all that is good is done by God.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 51:1
verses.text: Chapter LI.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 51:2
verses.text: —Evils Brought in by Sin.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 51:3
verses.text: "But by the freedom of the will, every man, while he is unbelieving in regard to things to come, by evil deeds runs into evils.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 51:4
verses.text: And these are the things in the world which seem to be done contrary to order, which owe their existence to unbelief.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 51:5
verses.text: Therefore the dispensation of divine providence is withal to be admired, which granted to those men in the beginning, walking in the good way of life, to enjoy incorruptible good things; but when they sinned, they gave birth to evil by sin.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 51:6
verses.text: And to every good thing evil is joined as by a certain covenant of alliance on the part of sin, since indeed the earth has been polluted with human blood, and altars have been lighted to demons, and they have polluted the very air by the filthy smoke of sacrifices; and so at length the elements, being first corrupted, have handed over to men the fault of their corruption, as roots communicate their qualities to the branches and the fruit.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 52:1
verses.text: Chapter LII.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 52:2
verses.text: —"No Rose Without Its Thorn".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 52:3
verses.text: "Observe therefore in this, as I have said, how justly divine providence comes to the help of things vitiated; that, inasmuch as evils which had derived their origin from sin were associated with the good things of God, He should assign two chiefs to these two departments.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 52:4
verses.text: And accordingly, to Him who rejoices in good He has appointed the ordering of good things, that He might bring those who believe in Him to the faith of His providence; but to him who rejoices in evil, He has given over those things which are done without order and uselessly, from which of course the faith of His providence comes into doubt; and thus a just division has been made by a just God.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 52:5
verses.text: Hence therefore it is, that whereas the orderly course of the stars produces faith that the world was made by the hand of a designer, on the other hand, the disturbance of the air, the pestilent breeze, the uncontrolled fire of the lightning, cast doubt upon the work of providence.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 52:6
verses.text: For, as we have said, every good thing has its corresponding contrary evil thing joined with it; as hail is opposite to the fertilizing showers, the corruption of mildew is associated with the gentle dew, the whirlwinds of storms are joined with the soft winds, unfruitful trees with fruitful, noxious herbs with useful, wild and destructive animals with gentle ones.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 52:7
verses.text: But all these things are arranged by God, because that the choice of men's will has departed from the purpose of good, and fallen away to evil.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 53:1
verses.text: Chapter LIII.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 53:2
verses.text: —Everything Has Its Corresponding Contrary.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 53:3
verses.text: "Therefore this division holds in all the things of the world; and as there are pious men, so there are also impious; as there are prophets, so also there are false prophets; and amongst the Gentiles there are philosophers and false philosophers.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 53:4
verses.text: Also the Arabian nations, and many others, have imitated the circumcision of the Jews for the service of their impiety.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 53:5
verses.text: So also the worship of demons is contrary to the divine worship, baptism to baptism, laws to the law, false apostles to apostles, and false teachers to teachers.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 53:6
verses.text: And hence it is that among the philosophers some assert providence, others deny it; some maintain that there is one God, others that there are more than one: in short, the matter has come to this, that whereas demons are expelled by the word of God, by which it is declared that there is a providence, the magical art, for the confirmation of infidelity, has found out ways of imitating this by contraries.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 53:7
verses.text: Thus has been discovered the method of counteracting the poison of serpents by incantations, and the effecting of cures contrary to the word and power of God.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 53:8
verses.text: The magic art has also found out ministries contrary to the angels of God, placing the calling up of souls and the figments of demons in opposition to these.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 53:9
verses.text: And, not to prolong the discourse by a further enumeration, there is nothing whatever that makes for the belief of providence, which has not something, on the other hand, prepared for unbelief; and therefore they who do not know that division of things, think that there is no providence, by reason of those things in the world which are discordant from themselves.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 53:10
verses.text: But do you, my father, as a wise man, choose from that division the part which preserves order and makes for the belief of providence, and do not only follow that part which runs against order and neutralizes the belief of providence".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 54:1
verses.text: Chapter LIV.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 54:2
verses.text: —An Illustration.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 54:3
verses.text: To this the old man answered: "Show me a way, my son, by which I may establish in my mind one or other of these two orders, the one of which asserts, and the other denies, providence".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 54:4
verses.text: "To one having a right judgment," says Aquila, "the decision is easy.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 54:5
verses.text: For this very thing that you say, order and disorder, may be produced by a contriver, but not by insensible nature.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 54:6
verses.text: For let us suppose, by way of illustration, that a great mass were torn from a high rock, and cast down headlong, and when clashed upon the ground were broken into many pieces, could it in any way happen that, amongst that multitude of fragments, there should be found even one which should have any perfect figure and shape?" The old man answered: "It is impossible".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 54:7
verses.text: "But," said Aquila, "if there be present a statuary, he can by his skilful hand and reasonable mind form the stone cut from the mountain into whatever figure he pleases".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 54:8
verses.text: The old man said: "That is true".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 54:9
verses.text: "Therefore," says Aquila, "when there is not a rational mind, no figure can be formed out of the mass; but when there is a designing mind, there may be both form and deformity: for example, if a workman cuts from the mountain a block to which he wishes to give a form, he must first cut it out unformed and rough; then, by degrees hammering and hewing it by the rule of his art, he expresses the form which he has conceived in his mind.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 54:10
verses.text: Thus, therefore, from informity or deformity, by the hand of the workman form is attained, and both proceed from the workman.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 54:11
verses.text: In like manner, therefore, the things which are done in the world are accomplished by the providence of a contriver, although they may seem not quite orderly.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 54:12
verses.text: And therefore, because these two ways have been made known to you, and you have heard the divisions of them, flee from the way of unbelief, lest haply it lead you to that prince who delights in evils; but follow the way of faith, that you may come to that King who delighteth in good men".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 55:1
verses.text: Chapter LV.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 55:2
verses.text: —The Two Kingdoms.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 55:3
verses.text: To this the old man answered: "But why was that prince made who delights in evil? And from what was he made? Or was he not made?" Aquila said: "The treatment of that subject belongs to another time; but that you may not go away altogether without an answer to this, I shall give a few hints on this subject also.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 55:4
verses.text: God, foreseeing all things before the creation of the world, knowing that the men who were to be would some of them indeed incline to good, but others to the opposite, assigned those who should choose the good to His own government and His own care, and called them His peculiar inheritance; but He gave over the government of those who should turn to evil to those angels who, not by their substance, but by opposition, were unwilling to remain with God, being corrupted by the vice of envy and pride.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 55:5
verses.text: Those, therefore, he made worthy princes of worthy subjects; yet he so delivered them over to those angels, that they have not the power of doing what they will against them, unless they transgress the bounds assigned to them from the beginning.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 55:6
verses.text: And this is the bound assigned, that unless one first do the will of the demons, the demons have no power over him".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 56:1
verses.text: Chapter LVI.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 56:2
verses.text: —Origin of Evil.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 56:3
verses.text: Then the old man said: "You have stated it excellently, my son.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 56:4
verses.text: It now remains only that you tell me whence is the substance of evil: for if it was made by God, the evil fruit shows that the root is in fault; for it appears that it also is of an evil nature.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 56:5
verses.text: But if this substance was co-eternal with God, how can that which was equally unproduced and co-eternal be subject to the other?" "It was not always," said Aquila; "but neither does it necessarily follow, if it was made by God, that its Creator should be thought to be such as is that which has been made by Him.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 56:6
verses.text: For indeed God made the substance of all things; but if a reasonable mind, which has been made by God, do not acquiesce in the laws of its Creator, and go beyond the bounds of the temperance prescribed to it, how does this reflect on the Creator? Or if there is any reason higher than this, we do not know it; for we cannot know anything perfectly, and especially concerning those things for our ignorance of which we are not to be judged.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 56:7
verses.text: But those things for which we are to be judged are most easy to be understood, and are despatched almost in a word.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 56:8
verses.text: For almost the whole rule of our actions is summed up in this, that what we are unwilling to suffer we should not do to others.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 56:9
verses.text: For as you would not be killed, you must beware of killing another; and as you would not have your own marriage violated, you must not defile another's bed; you would not be stolen from, neither must you steal; and every matter of men's actions is comprehended within this rule".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 57:1
verses.text: Chapter LVII.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 57:2
verses.text: —The Old Man Unconvinced.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 57:3
verses.text: Then the old man: "Do not take amiss, my son, what I am going to say.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 57:4
verses.text: Though your words are powerful, yet they cannot lead me to believe that anything can be done apart from Genesis.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 57:5
verses.text: For I know that all things have happened to me by the necessity of Genesis, and therefore I cannot be persuaded that either to do well or to do ill is in our power; and if we have not our actions in our power, it cannot be believed that there is a judgment to come, by which either punishments may be inflicted on the evil, or rewards bestowed on the good.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 57:6
verses.text: In short, since I see that you are initiated in this sort of learning, I shall lay before you a few things from the art itself".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 57:7
verses.text: "If," says Aquila, "you wish to add anything from that science, my brother Clement will answer you with all care, since he has attended more fully to the science of mathematics.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 57:8
verses.text: For I can maintain in other ways that our actions are in our own power; but I ought not to presume upon those things which I have not learned".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 58:1
verses.text: Chapter LVIII.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 58:2
verses.text: —Sitting in Judgment Upon God.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 58:3
verses.text: When Aquila had thus spoken, then I Clement said: "To-morrow, my father, you shall speak as you please, and we will gladly hear you; for I suppose it will also be gratifying to you that you have to do with those who are not ignorant of the science which you profess".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 58:4
verses.text: When, therefore, it had been settled between the old man and me, that on the following day we should hold a discussion on the subject of Genesis—whether all things are done under its influence, or there be anything in us which is not done by Genesis, but by the judgment of the mind—Peter rose up, and began to speak to the following effect: "To me it is exceedingly wonderful, that things which can easily be found out men make difficult by recondite thoughts and words; and those especially who think themselves wise, and who, wishing to comprehend the will of God, treat God as if He were a man, yea, as if He were something less than a man: for no one can know the purpose or mind of a man unless he himself reveal his thoughts; and neither can any one learn a profession unless he be for a long time instructed by a master.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 58:5
verses.text: How much more must it be, that no one can know the mind or the work of the invisible and incomprehensible God, unless He Himself send a prophet to declare His purpose, and expound the way of His creation, so far as it is lawful for men to learn it! Hence I think it ridiculous when men judge of the power of God in natural ways, and think that this is possible and that impossible to Him, or this greater and that less, while they are ignorant of everything; who, being unrighteous men, judge the righteous God; unskilled, judge the contriver; corrupt, judge the incorruptible; creatures, judge the Creator.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 59:1
verses.text: Chapter LIX.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 59:2
verses.text: —The True Prophet.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 59:3
verses.text: But I would not have you think, that in saying this I take away the power of judging concerning things; but I give counsel that no one walk through devious places, and rush into errors without end.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 59:4
verses.text: And therefore I advise not only wise men, but indeed all men who have a desire of knowing what is advantageous to them, that they seek after the true Prophet; for it is He alone who knoweth all things, and who knoweth what and how every man is seeking.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 59:5
verses.text: For He is within the mind of every one of us, but in those who have no desire of the knowledge of God and His righteousness, He is inoperative; but He works in those who seek after that which is profitable to their souls, and kindles in them the light of knowledge.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 59:6
verses.text: Wherefore seek Him first of all; and if you do not find Him, expect not that you shall learn anything from any other.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 59:7
verses.text: But He is soon found by those who diligently seek Him through love of the truth, and whose souls are not taken possession of by wickedness.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 59:8
verses.text: For He is present with those who desire Him in the innocency of their spirits, who bear patiently, and draw sighs from the bottom of their hearts through love of the truth; but He deserts malevolent minds, because as a prophet He knows the thoughts of every one.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 59:9
verses.text: And therefore let no one think that he can find Him by his own wisdom, unless, as we have said, he empty his mind of all wickedness, and conceive a pure and faithful desire to know Him.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 59:10
verses.text: For when any one has so prepared himself, He Himself as a prophet, seeing a mind prepared for Him, of His own accord offers Himself to his knowledge.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 60:1
verses.text: Chapter LX.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 60:2
verses.text: —His Deliverances Not to Be Questioned.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 60:3
verses.text: "Therefore, if any one wishes to learn all things, he cannot do it by discussing them one by one; for, being mortal, he shall not be able to trace the counsel of God, and to scan immensity itself.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 60:4
verses.text: But if, as we have said, he desires to learn all things, let him seek after the true Prophet; and when he has found Him, let him not treat with Him by questions and disputations and arguments; but if He has given any response, or pronounced any judgment, it cannot be doubted that this is certain.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 60:5
verses.text: And therefore, before all things, let the true Prophet be sought, and His words be laid hold of.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 60:6
verses.text: In respect to these this only should be discussed by every one, that he may satisfy himself if they are truly His prophetic words; that is, if they contain undoubted faith of things to come, if they mark out definite times, if they preserve the order of things, if they do not relate as last those things which are first, nor as first those things which were done last, if they contain nothing subtle, nothing composed by magic art to deceive, or if they have not transferred to themselves things which were revealed to others, and have mixed them with falsehoods.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 60:7
verses.text: And when, all these things having been discussed by right judgment, it is established that they are prophetic words, so they ought to be at once believed concerning all things on which they have spoken and answered.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 61:1
verses.text: Chapter LXI.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 61:2
verses.text: —Ignorance of the Philosophers.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 61:3
verses.text: "For let us consider carefully the work of divine providence.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 61:4
verses.text: For whereas the philosophers have introduced certain subtile and difficult words, so that not even the terms that they use in their discourses can be known and understood by all, God has shown that those who thought themselves word-framers are altogether unskilful as respects the knowledge of the truth.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 61:5
verses.text: For the knowledge of things which is imparted by the true Prophet is simple, and plain, and brief; which those men walking through devious places, and through the stony difficulties of words, are wholly ignorant of.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 61:6
verses.text: Therefore, to modest and simple minds, when they see things come to pass which have been foretold, it is enough, and more than enough, that they may receive most certain knowledge from most certain prescience; and for the rest may be at peace, having received evident knowledge of the truth.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 61:7
verses.text: For all other things are treated by opinion, in which there can be nothing firm.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 61:8
verses.text: For what speech is there which may not be contradicted? And what argument is there that may not be overthrown by another argument? And hence it is, that by disputation of this sort men can never come to any end of knowledge and learning, but find the end of their life sooner than the end of their questions.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 62:1
verses.text: Chapter LXII.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 62:2
verses.text: —End of the Conference.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 62:3
verses.text: "And, therefore, since amongst these philosophers are things uncertain, we must come to the true Prophet.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 62:4
verses.text: Him God the Father wished to be loved by all, and accordingly He has been pleased wholly to extinguish those opinions which have originated with men, and in regard to which there is nothing like certainty—that He the true Prophet might be the more sought after, and that He whom they had obscured should show to men the way of truth.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 62:5
verses.text: For on this account also God made the world, and by Him the world is filled; whence also He is everywhere near to them who seek Him, though He be sought in the remotest ends of the earth.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 62:6
verses.text: But if any one seek Him not purely, nor holily, nor faithfully, He is indeed within him, because He is everywhere, and is found within the minds of all men; but, as we have said before, He is dormant to the unbelieving, and is held to be absent from those by whom His existence is not believed".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 62:7
verses.text: And when Peter had said this, and more to the same effect, concerning the true Prophet, he dismissed the crowds; and when he very earnestly entreated the old man to remain with us, he could prevail nothing; but he also departed, to return next day, as had been agreed upon.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book VIII 62:8
verses.text: And after this, we also, with Peter, went to our lodging, and enjoyed our accustomed food and rest.
